snippet: Political contests, by definition, typically have a winner and a loser. But in California, if final polls have it right, one of Tuesday's contests is going to produce two losers: the Democratic and Republican parties and, beyond that, maybe the wh...
lead_paragraph: Political contests, by definition, typically have a winner and a loser. But in California, if final polls have it right, one of Tuesday's contests is going to produce two losers: the Democratic and Republican parties and, beyond that, maybe the whole state. On the ballot is an obscure proposal, labeled Proposition 3, that calls for the state to revert to ''closed'' primaries, as opposed to ''open'' primaries, when choosing Presidential candidates.
abstract: California voters to decide whether to return to closed Presidential primaries, in which only registered Democrats and Republicans may cast ballots; two parties refuse to send delgates chosen in open primaries, system now used in California; old system will have to be brought back if state is to be bigger player in Presidential nominating game (S)

headline.main: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: Political Briefing; If Primary Plan Loses, California May, Too
